elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Two MOFs were synthesized solvothermally by adjusting reactant ratio. The MOFs represent unusual noninterpenetrating 3D frameworks. MOF 1 is rarely one example of clusters-based frameworks with tetranuclear, dinuclear subunits inside of cage-like and paddle-wheel fragments. Notably, both of the frameworks accommodate infinite open 1D nanosized channels.

elements.clean_text:
Two MOFs were synthesized solvothermally by adjusting ratio of reactant.

Both complexes were characterized by elemental analysis, FT-IR, single-crystal XRD, PXRD and TGA techniques.

The MOFs represent unusual nanoporous 3D frameworks.

MOF 1 is rarely one example of clusters-based frameworks.

Abstract

From the same starting materials, two novel metal-organic frameworks, namely {(cation)[Cu4(bptca)2(OH)(H2O)2]⋅x(solvent)} n  (1) and {(cation)[Cu3(bptca)2(H2O)3]⋅y(solvent)} n  (2) (H4bptca=biphenyl-2,3,3',5'-tetracarboxylic acid), have been synthesized through the linkage of Cu2(COO)4 paddle-wheel clusters. The complex 1 possesses both dinuclear [Cu2O2] subunits encapsulated into cage-like units and tetranuclear [Cu4(μ 3-OH)2] clusters, which exhibits an unusual 3D 4-nodal (4,4,4,8)-connected network with {412.812.104}{43.83}4{46}{86} topology. Reducing the metal-to-ligand ratio, the other 3D (4,4)-connected framework 2 with {42.84} PtS-type topology was constructed under the intervention of mononuclear Cu(bptca)2 and single Cu2(COO)4 paddle-wheel supporting layers. Notably, both of the frameworks 1 and 2 accommodate infinite open 1D nanosized quadrate channels.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st025">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">The engineering of porous coordination polymers, also known as metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), tends to be the most rapidly investigated area not only due to their intriguing architectures but also being potential functional materials probably in diverse areas . Indeed, the pore apertures of MOFs determine the size of the guest molecules, which embodies those functional features as a carrier. In general, the construction of porous structural topologies immensely depends on the organic ligands and the coordination geometry of central metal ions . One successful strategy for making large porous MOFs and avoiding appearance of interpenetration is to construct a framework by the “short axis – long axis” mode . The design solution can maintain a short axis with the long organic links inclined to that axis. The short axis by metal–oxygen bonds is the distance between the long organic links of ligand skeleton along that axis joining the secondary building units (SBUs), and effectively eliminates the possibility of framework interpenetration. Conceptually, the main efforts are centered around the choice of suitable organic multicarboxylate ligands . Among various multicarboxylate ligands, asymmetrical carboxylate ligands have been reported rarely in the fabrication of MOFs . Those can be utilized to form large porous MOFs because of their asymmetrical nature in favor of the short axis – long axis arrangement, in which the organic carbon backbone acts as the longer linkage with the asymmetrical carboxyls leaning against the backbone as the short rods . Meanwhile, the twisted conformations of asymmetrical carboxyl ligands benefit the generation of polynuclear metal clusters for addressing that strategy .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The engineering of porous coordination polymers, also known as metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), tends to be the most rapidly investigated area not only due to their intriguing architectures but also being potential functional materials probably in diverse areas . Indeed, the pore apertures of MOFs determine the size of the guest molecules, which embodies those functional features as a carrier. In general, the construction of porous structural topologies immensely depends on the organic ligands and the coordination geometry of central metal ions . One successful strategy for making large porous MOFs and avoiding appearance of interpenetration is to construct a framework by the "short axis - long axis" mode . The design solution can maintain a short axis with the long organic links inclined to that axis. The short axis by metal-oxygen bonds is the distance between the long organic links of ligand skeleton along that axis joining the secondary building units (SBUs), and effectively eliminates the possibility of framework interpenetration. Conceptually, the main efforts are centered around the choice of suitable organic multicarboxylate ligands . Among various multicarboxylate ligands, asymmetrical carboxylate ligands have been reported rarely in the fabrication of MOFs . Those can be utilized to form large porous MOFs because of their asymmetrical nature in favor of the short axis - long axis arrangement, in which the organic carbon backbone acts as the longer linkage with the asymmetrical carboxyls leaning against the backbone as the short rods . Meanwhile, the twisted conformations of asymmetrical carboxyl ligands benefit the generation of polynuclear metal clusters for addressing that strategy .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Taking these into consideration, we chose biphenyl-2,3,3′,5′-tetracarboxylic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bptca) ligand to build MOFs, and the asymmetrical carboxyl-rich ligand may be show miscellaneous coordination modes and build complicated high-connected frameworks due to the rotation of phenyl and carboxylate groups. To the best of our knowledge, only cluster-based [Tb(Hbptca)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, [Mn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(bptca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>, [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(bptca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(DMF)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> and several other single-nodal MOFs have been reported up to date . Using the binary Cu(II)/H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bptca system under the solvothermal conditions, we have prepared two novel MOFs {(cation)[Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(bptca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>(solvent)}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and {(cation)[Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(bptca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]·<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>(solvent)}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>). Interestingly, two MOFs show unusual nanoporous 3D noninterpenetrating frameworks with various polynuclear metal clusters and intriguing topological features, as (4,4,4,8)-connected {4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>.8<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>.10<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>}{4<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>.8<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>}<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>{4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>}{8<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>} topology for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, and (4,4)-connected {4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.8<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>} PtS-type topology for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Taking these into consideration, we chose biphenyl-2,3,3',5'-tetracarboxylic acid (H4bptca) ligand to build MOFs, and the asymmetrical carboxyl-rich ligand may be show miscellaneous coordination modes and build complicated high-connected frameworks due to the rotation of phenyl and carboxylate groups. To the best of our knowledge, only cluster-based [Tb(Hbptca)(H2O)2]⋅H2O, [Mn4(bptca)2(bpy)2] n , [Cd4(bptca)2(DMF)4] n  and several other single-nodal MOFs have been reported up to date . Using the binary Cu(II)/H4bptca system under the solvothermal conditions, we have prepared two novel MOFs {(cation)[Cu4(bptca)2(OH)(H2O)2]⋅x(solvent)} n  (1) and {(cation)[Cu3(bptca)2(H2O)3]⋅y(solvent)} n  (2). Interestingly, two MOFs show unusual nanoporous 3D noninterpenetrating frameworks with various polynuclear metal clusters and intriguing topological features, as (4,4,4,8)-connected {412.812.104}{43.83}4{46}{86} topology for 1, and (4,4)-connected {42.84} PtS-type topology for 2.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st030">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st035">Materials and measurements</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">All reagents and solvents of analytical grade were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. Elemental analyses for C, H and N were recorded on the Elementar model VarioEL III instrument. FTIR spectra were obtained in KBr pellets on a Nicolet Avatar 360 FTIR spectrometer in the 400–4000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> region. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded with a Rigaku D/Max 3III diffractometer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were determined with a Netzsch STA449C apparatus under a nitrogen stream using at a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and measurements

All reagents and solvents of analytical grade were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. Elemental analyses for C, H and N were recorded on the Elementar model VarioEL III instrument. FTIR spectra were obtained in KBr pellets on a Nicolet Avatar 360 FTIR spectrometer in the 400-4000cm-1 region. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded with a Rigaku D/Max 3III diffractometer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were determined with a Netzsch STA449C apparatus under a nitrogen stream using at a heating rate of 10°Cmin-1.

<ce:section-title id="st040">Syntheses of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Synthesis of {(cation)[Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(bptca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>(solvent)}<ce:italic>

Syntheses of complexes 1 and 2

<ce:section-title id="st045">Crystallographic data collection and refinement</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">Data were collected at room temperature with a single-crystal Bruker Apex II Image Plate CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation source (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) operating at 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kV and 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mA in ω scan mode for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. A multi-scan absorption correction was applied with the use of <ce:small-caps>sadabs</ce:small-caps>. The structures were solved by direct methods using the <ce:small-caps>sir</ce:small-caps>92 program or <ce:small-caps>shelxs</ce:small-caps>-97, and then refined with full matrix least-square methods based on F<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> (<ce:small-caps>shelx</ce:small-caps>-2013) within the <ce:small-caps>wingx</ce:small-caps> program . Because the guest solvent molecules and free ions are highly disordered and impossible to refine using conventional discrete-atom models, the <ce:small-caps>squeeze</ce:small-caps> subroutine of the <ce:small-caps>platon</ce:small-caps> software suite was applied to remove the scattering from the highly disordered solvent molecules and anion ions, and sets of new diffraction intensities were produced. The large thermal parameters of water are caused by slight disorder. Atoms O10 in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are disordered into two positions with site occupancies of 0.5 and 0.5. All hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically except coordinated water molecule, which were located from Fourier maps. Crystal data for two complexes are shown in . Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic data collection and refinement

Data were collected at room temperature with a single-crystal Bruker Apex II Image Plate CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation source (λ =0.71073Å) operating at 50kV and 30mA in ω scan mode for 1 and 2. A multi-scan absorption correction was applied with the use of sadabs. The structures were solved by direct methods using the sir92 program or shelxs-97, and then refined with full matrix least-square methods based on F2 (shelx-2013) within the wingx program . Because the guest solvent molecules and free ions are highly disordered and impossible to refine using conventional discrete-atom models, the squeeze subroutine of the platon software suite was applied to remove the scattering from the highly disordered solvent molecules and anion ions, and sets of new diffraction intensities were produced. The large thermal parameters of water are caused by slight disorder. Atoms O10 in 2 are disordered into two positions with site occupancies of 0.5 and 0.5. All hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically except coordinated water molecule, which were located from Fourier maps. Crystal data for two complexes are shown in . Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in .

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st050">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st055">Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">MOFs <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are built from almost the same reaction conditions, except for the metal/ligand ratio. The reactant ratio seems to play a key role for the construction of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, because our attempts of the reactant ratio variation under the certain external experimental conditions have led to these complexes rather than any other interesting products formation. The experiments with variation of the reactant ratio also disclosed the critical value of stoichiometric ratios of used precursors on the formation of the complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, respectively. The result suggests that the reaction is sensitive to the reactant ratio.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis

MOFs 1 and 2 are built from almost the same reaction conditions, except for the metal/ligand ratio. The reactant ratio seems to play a key role for the construction of complexes 1 and 2, because our attempts of the reactant ratio variation under the certain external experimental conditions have led to these complexes rather than any other interesting products formation. The experiments with variation of the reactant ratio also disclosed the critical value of stoichiometric ratios of used precursors on the formation of the complexes 1 and 2, respectively. The result suggests that the reaction is sensitive to the reactant ratio.

elements.clean_text:
Description of the crystal structures

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 1 shows a 3D anionic framework with three kinds of polynuclear clusters and 1D channels occupied by unknown charge-balancing guest solvent molecules. Complex 1 crystallizes in triclinic space group   P   1   ¯    . There are four Cu(II) ions, two bptca4 - ligands, one OH- group and two coordinated water molecules in the asymmetric coordination unit of 1 ( a). Presumably, [(CH3)2NH2]+ decomposed from DMA and H3O+ might be inclosed into the channels to fit the global charge balance of anionic framework . The guest cations are severely disordered, but whether the confirmation of the guest solvent molecules has little influence on the exploration of main frameworks. Cu1, Cu2 and Cu3 centers are five-coordinated, residing in a distorted square pyramidal geometry. Each Cu1 atom is linked with four oxygen atoms of four carboxylate groups from four bptca4 - linkers and one coordinated water molecule (Cu1-O 1.958(6)-2.144(9)Å), Cu2 center is coordinated to four oxygen atoms from four separate bptca4 - ligands and one oxygen atom of one hydroxyl (Cu2-O 1.916(5)-2.216(6)Å), while Cu3 is bridged by three carboxylate oxygen atoms of three bptca4- anions and two hydroxyl oxygen atoms (Cu3-O 1.923(6)-2.207(6)Å). Cu4 adopts a distorted octahedral geometry defined by five oxygen atoms of four carboxylate groups from three bptca4 - linkers in consideration of a nonnegligible Cu4-O16 interaction of 2.653Å and one coordinate water ligand (Cu4-O 1.925(6)-2.384(5)Å). For the two independent bptca4 - anions in 1, one exhibits a μ8-bridging mode with the carboxylate groups in μ2-η1:η1 and μ2-η1:η2 fashions ( a). The other tetracarboxylate features a μ6-bridging mode with μ2-η1:η1 and μ1-η1:η0 fashions of carboxylate groups (b).

<ce:para id="p0060" view="all">Two Cu2 and two Cu3 construct papilionaceous tetranuclear [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] cluster through the bonding of two bridging <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH and eight carboxylate groups of eight bptca<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands (b). It should be noted that the introduction of inorganic anions, such as OH<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, O<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and X<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> (X<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>halogen), plays a very important role in the formation of stable polynuclear clusters . The [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] cores are maintained by four different bptca<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands to extend into one 1D chain along the opposite directions. The most interesting feature is that four bptca<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions and two terminal [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] SBUs interlink to form a cage-like unit with diameter of 6.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å propped up by parallelogram dinuclear [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] SBU, in which the dimer copper SBUs are constructed by two Cu4 surrounding with six bridging carboxylates of bptca<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> from the encircling cage. In the cross side of the wide chain, two Cu1 atoms are bridged by four carboxylates in the bidentate-chelating mode to give a paddle-wheel shaped Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> subunit with the Cu–Cu distance of 2.6674(18)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Although the metal clusters were well investigated, the clusters-based framework materials with the coexistence of multiple polynuclear cluster SBUs have been seldom documented .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Two Cu2 and two Cu3 construct papilionaceous tetranuclear [Cu4(μ 3-OH)2] cluster through the bonding of two bridging μ 3-OH and eight carboxylate groups of eight bptca4 - ligands (b). It should be noted that the introduction of inorganic anions, such as OH-, O2 - and X- (X=halogen), plays a very important role in the formation of stable polynuclear clusters . The [Cu4(μ 3-OH)2] cores are maintained by four different bptca4 - ligands to extend into one 1D chain along the opposite directions. The most interesting feature is that four bptca4 - anions and two terminal [Cu4(μ 3-OH)2] SBUs interlink to form a cage-like unit with diameter of 6.6Å propped up by parallelogram dinuclear [Cu2O2] SBU, in which the dimer copper SBUs are constructed by two Cu4 surrounding with six bridging carboxylates of bptca4 - from the encircling cage. In the cross side of the wide chain, two Cu1 atoms are bridged by four carboxylates in the bidentate-chelating mode to give a paddle-wheel shaped Cu2(COO)4 subunit with the Cu-Cu distance of 2.6674(18)Å. Although the metal clusters were well investigated, the clusters-based framework materials with the coexistence of multiple polynuclear cluster SBUs have been seldom documented .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0065" view="all">Significantly, the assembly of paddle-wheel clusters as rigid SBUs with polytopic carboxylate linkers could generate rigid porous frameworks with permanent porosity and open functionalized metal sites . As a consequence, Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> paddle-wheel subunits for different orientations act as square SBUs linking 1D chains to provide a 3D framework with regular 1D parallelogram nanosized channels along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis (grid dimensions of 10.55<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>9.42<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>, calculated from the neighboring Cu(II) atoms) (c). Furthermore, two different kinds of square apertures are present. The first one is polar owing to the effective pore surface occupied mainly by uncoordinate carboxylate oxygen atoms and coordinate aqua molecules, and the twisted benzenyl groups of bptca<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> take up the second hydrophobic channels. When seen from <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>×</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>b</ce:italic> plane, the framework structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is closely compact (), and thus, show noninterpenetrating single network, which depends on the asymmetrical nature of the bptca<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> molecules possessing long molecular backbone to stretch space and large metal clusters laterally to block the interpenetrating aisles. A calculation using <ce:small-caps>platon</ce:small-caps> revealed that the potential total solvent-accessible void space of the framework is 1072.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, corresponding to the 43.5% of the unit cell volume 2466.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
. From the view of topology, the SBUs of dimer [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] subunit and tetranuclear [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] cluster serve as 4-connected and 8-connected nodes, respectively. The bptca<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands show two kinds of coordinated modes, but both of them link four copper-based SBUs, and thus, the organic ligands act as 4-connected nodes. So, the whole 3D framework adopts an unusual tetranodal (4,4,4,8)-connected net with the point symbol of {4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>.8<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>.10<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>}{4<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>.8<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>}<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>{4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>}{8<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>} (d).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Significantly, the assembly of paddle-wheel clusters as rigid SBUs with polytopic carboxylate linkers could generate rigid porous frameworks with permanent porosity and open functionalized metal sites . As a consequence, Cu2(COO)4 paddle-wheel subunits for different orientations act as square SBUs linking 1D chains to provide a 3D framework with regular 1D parallelogram nanosized channels along the a axis (grid dimensions of 10.55×9.42Å2, calculated from the neighboring Cu(II) atoms) (c). Furthermore, two different kinds of square apertures are present. The first one is polar owing to the effective pore surface occupied mainly by uncoordinate carboxylate oxygen atoms and coordinate aqua molecules, and the twisted benzenyl groups of bptca4 - take up the second hydrophobic channels. When seen from a  ×  b plane, the framework structure of 1 is closely compact (), and thus, show noninterpenetrating single network, which depends on the asymmetrical nature of the bptca4 - molecules possessing long molecular backbone to stretch space and large metal clusters laterally to block the interpenetrating aisles. A calculation using platon revealed that the potential total solvent-accessible void space of the framework is 1072.2Å3, corresponding to the 43.5% of the unit cell volume 2466.1Å3 . From the view of topology, the SBUs of dimer [Cu2O2] subunit and tetranuclear [Cu4(μ 3-OH)2] cluster serve as 4-connected and 8-connected nodes, respectively. The bptca4 - ligands show two kinds of coordinated modes, but both of them link four copper-based SBUs, and thus, the organic ligands act as 4-connected nodes. So, the whole 3D framework adopts an unusual tetranodal (4,4,4,8)-connected net with the point symbol of {412.812.104}{43.83}4{46}{86} (d).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0070" view="all">Except for the molar ratio variation of reactants, the assembly of the same starting materials as those of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> offers the other complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, in which single Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> paddle-wheel supporting layers interacting with mononuclear Cu(bptca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> result in a 3D anionic nanoporous framework. Single-crystal XRD analysis makes clear that complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with space group <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>a, the asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> contains three Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions, two deprotoned bptca<ce:sup loc="post">4-</ce:sup> ligands, three coordinated water molecules. Fitting the global charge balance of anionic nanoporous framework <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> from the same starting materials as <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> should be similar to that of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Each Cu(II) center is five-coordinated mode of distorted square pyramidal geometry. Cu1 is coordinated by four oxygen atoms from four carboxylate groups of four isophthalate moieties of four bptca<ce:sup loc="post">4-</ce:sup> (Cu1–O 1.957(5)–1.987(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) and one oxygen atom from one terminal water (Cu1–O9 2.134(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). Whereas, the mononuclear Cu2 is surrounded by four oxygen atoms of four monodentate carboxylates from two phthalates of two bptca<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> in the equatorial positions (Cu2–O 1.869(9)–1.951(9)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), and the axial oxygen atom of coordinated aqua molecule (Cu2–O10 2.408(18)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The bptca<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligand exhibits a unique μ<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>-bridging mode with the carboxylate groups in μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> and μ<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>–η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup> fashions (c).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Except for the molar ratio variation of reactants, the assembly of the same starting materials as those of 1 offers the other complex 2, in which single Cu2(COO)4 paddle-wheel supporting layers interacting with mononuclear Cu(bptca)2 result in a 3D anionic nanoporous framework. Single-crystal XRD analysis makes clear that complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with space group C2/c. As shown in  a, the asymmetric unit of 2 contains three Cu2+ ions, two deprotoned bptca4- ligands, three coordinated water molecules. Fitting the global charge balance of anionic nanoporous framework 2 from the same starting materials as 1 should be similar to that of complex 1. Each Cu(II) center is five-coordinated mode of distorted square pyramidal geometry. Cu1 is coordinated by four oxygen atoms from four carboxylate groups of four isophthalate moieties of four bptca4- (Cu1-O 1.957(5)-1.987(5)Å) and one oxygen atom from one terminal water (Cu1-O9 2.134(6)Å). Whereas, the mononuclear Cu2 is surrounded by four oxygen atoms of four monodentate carboxylates from two phthalates of two bptca4 - in the equatorial positions (Cu2-O 1.869(9)-1.951(9)Å), and the axial oxygen atom of coordinated aqua molecule (Cu2-O10 2.408(18)Å). The bptca4 - ligand exhibits a unique μ5-bridging mode with the carboxylate groups in μ2-η1:η1 and μ1-η1:η0 fashions (c).

<ce:para id="p0075" view="all">So far, the anionic forms of biphenyl-2,3,3′,5′-tetracarboxylic acid have a poor performance in Coordination Chemistry. In reported MOFs, most of the organic links present incomplete deprotonation of the carboxylic acid . The remain three documented cases show the completely-deprotonated carboxyl groups of organic moieties with bptca<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligand acting as μ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-bridging and μ<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>-bridging mode. The μ<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>-bridging mode other than that of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, integrates μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> and μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>–η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> fashions of carboxylate groups . Newly, we found two different μ<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>-bridge fashions of bptca<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands for η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-μ<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf> and η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-μ<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf> modes .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: So far, the anionic forms of biphenyl-2,3,3',5'-tetracarboxylic acid have a poor performance in Coordination Chemistry. In reported MOFs, most of the organic links present incomplete deprotonation of the carboxylic acid . The remain three documented cases show the completely-deprotonated carboxyl groups of organic moieties with bptca4 - ligand acting as μ4-bridging and μ8-bridging mode. The μ8-bridging mode other than that of complex 1, integrates μ2-η1:η1 and μ3-η1:η2 fashions of carboxylate groups . Newly, we found two different μ8-bridge fashions of bptca4 - ligands for η1:η3:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1-μ8 and η1:η3:η1:η2:η1:η1:η1:η1-μ8 modes .

Due to the different coordination environment of Cu atoms, the respective paddle-wheel units in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, also display some differences, which each bptca<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>

The Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> fragment gets ulteriorly incorporation with four neighboring paddle-wheel clusters <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> two bidentate bridging carboxylate groups of isophthalate to give a single Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> paddle-wheel supporting grid structure. These 2D layers are linked in the third direction by folded mononuclear Cu(bptc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> units, to form a 3D nanoporous framework (c). Similar to <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the framework accommodates infinite open 1D quadrate channels with 11.20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å caliber (Cu…Cu distance). Meanwhile, the closely arrangement of the components on the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>

The potential solvent-accessible volume of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is 2129.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, which corresponds to 42.7% of unit cell volume 4991.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> according to the <ce:small-caps>platon</ce:small-caps> calculations . From the viewpoint of the network topology, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> possesses 3D (4,4)-connected binodal frameworks with {4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.8<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>} PtS-type topology, by considering each mononuclear Cu(bptca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and paddle-wheel Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> clusters as 4-connected nodes (d).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Two adjacent Cu1 ions are linked by four bidentate bridging carboxylate groups to afford a paddle-wheel Cu2(COO)4 subunit with the Cu-Cu distance of 2.6391(18)Å, being shorter than that of complex 1 (b). Due to the different coordination environment of Cu atoms, the respective paddle-wheel units in 1 and 2, also display some differences, which each bptca4 - ligand of 1 connects only one paddle-wheel cluster and the cation of 2 does two paddle-wheel clusters. The Cu2(COO)4 fragment gets ulteriorly incorporation with four neighboring paddle-wheel clusters via two bidentate bridging carboxylate groups of isophthalate to give a single Cu2(COO)4 paddle-wheel supporting grid structure. These 2D layers are linked in the third direction by folded mononuclear Cu(bptc)2 units, to form a 3D nanoporous framework (c). Similar to 1, the framework accommodates infinite open 1D quadrate channels with 11.20Å caliber (Cu…Cu distance). Meanwhile, the closely arrangement of the components on the a  ×  b or a  ×  c plane suggests the noninterpenetrating features of the final framework (). The potential solvent-accessible volume of 2 is 2129.5Å3, which corresponds to 42.7% of unit cell volume 4991.0Å3 according to the platon calculations . From the viewpoint of the network topology, 2 possesses 3D (4,4)-connected binodal frameworks with {42.84} PtS-type topology, by considering each mononuclear Cu(bptca)2 and paddle-wheel Cu2(COO)4 clusters as 4-connected nodes (d).

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st065">IR spectroscopy</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">The characteristic bands observer at 3422<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 3426<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> suggest the stretching vibrations <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>OH) of hydrogen bonds. There is no absorption peaks around 1700<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup>, which indicates that all carboxyl groups (<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>COOH) of the organic ligands are deprotonated completely<ce:italic>.</ce:italic> The asymmetric and symmetric vibrations peaks of the carboxylate groups can be found at 1622 and 1384<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, and 1610 and 1429<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
IR spectroscopy

The characteristic bands observer at 3422cm-1 for 1 and 3426cm-1 for 2 suggest the stretching vibrations ν(OH) of hydrogen bonds. There is no absorption peaks around 1700cm-1, which indicates that all carboxyl groups (COOH) of the organic ligands are deprotonated completely. The asymmetric and symmetric vibrations peaks of the carboxylate groups can be found at 1622 and 1384cm-1 for 1, and 1610 and 1429cm-1 for 2.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st070">XRPD and thermal analysis</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0090" view="all">The phase purities of the bulk products of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, which were characterized by X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) at room temperature, were confirmed by comparison of their powder diffraction patterns with those simulated from the single-crystal study (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
XRPD and thermal analysis

The phase purities of the bulk products of 1 and 2, which were characterized by X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) at room temperature, were confirmed by comparison of their powder diffraction patterns with those simulated from the single-crystal study ( ).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0095" view="all">Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are air-stable and can retain the crystalline integrity at ambient conditions. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) show that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> have onset weight losses within the temperature range of 125–240<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and 110–205<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, respectively (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>). The first steps of TGA curves correspond to the release of the unknown disordered solvent molecules. Almost without pause, the host MOFs begin to decompose continuously until the final products CuO obtained. Consequently, the final MOFs exhibit ordinary thermal stability, which can be attributed to the anion nature of the frameworks strengthened by charge-balancing guest cations.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Complexes 1 and 2 are air-stable and can retain the crystalline integrity at ambient conditions. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) show that 1 and 2 have onset weight losses within the temperature range of 125-240°C and 110-205°C, respectively ( ). The first steps of TGA curves correspond to the release of the unknown disordered solvent molecules. Almost without pause, the host MOFs begin to decompose continuously until the final products CuO obtained. Consequently, the final MOFs exhibit ordinary thermal stability, which can be attributed to the anion nature of the frameworks strengthened by charge-balancing guest cations.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st075">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0100" view="all">In summary, through careful consideration of asymmetrical carboxyl-rich ligand, biphenyl-2,3,3′,5′-tetracarboxylic acid, two distinct nanoporous Cu-MOFs are constructed by modification of reactant ratio. The asymmetrical “short axis – long axis” nature of the ligand possessing long molecular backbone and inclined carboxyls leads to the noninterpenetrating features of the synthesized complexes with high porosity. It also shows a rare example of clusters-based framework with the coexistence of triple polynuclear cluster SBUs of tetranuclear [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] clusters, dinuclear [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] clusters surrounded by cage-like units, and [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] paddle-wheel fragments. Whereas, the MOF <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows the structural changes with less complicated mononuclear Cu(bptca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and paddle-wheel Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>. The results reveal the importance of synthetic strategy and external factors such as reactant ratio for structural designing of porous MOFs. Thus, it could be predicted that more porous MOFs with fascinating structural merits and adsorption properties are to be designed and constructed under control.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, through careful consideration of asymmetrical carboxyl-rich ligand, biphenyl-2,3,3',5'-tetracarboxylic acid, two distinct nanoporous Cu-MOFs are constructed by modification of reactant ratio. The asymmetrical "short axis - long axis" nature of the ligand possessing long molecular backbone and inclined carboxyls leads to the noninterpenetrating features of the synthesized complexes with high porosity. It also shows a rare example of clusters-based framework with the coexistence of triple polynuclear cluster SBUs of tetranuclear [Cu4(μ 3-OH)2] clusters, dinuclear [Cu2O2] clusters surrounded by cage-like units, and [Cu2(COO)4] paddle-wheel fragments. Whereas, the MOF 2 shows the structural changes with less complicated mononuclear Cu(bptca)2 and paddle-wheel Cu2(COO)4. The results reveal the importance of synthetic strategy and external factors such as reactant ratio for structural designing of porous MOFs. Thus, it could be predicted that more porous MOFs with fascinating structural merits and adsorption properties are to be designed and constructed under control.

Syntheses of complexes 1 and 2 

Synthesis of {(cation)[Cu4(bptca)2(OH)(H2O)2]⋅x(solvent)} n  (1). A mixture of H4bptca (0.082g, 0.25mmol), Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.121g, 0.5mmol), and two drops of concentrated HNO3 (63%, aq.) in distilled water (3mL) and DMA (3mL) was placed in a 10mL screw-capped vial, heated to 105°C for 72h, and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5°Cmin-1. Yield: 42% based on copper. Elemental analyses (%): C, 47.35; H, 2.96; N, 4.37. <ce:section-title id="st060">Description of the crystal structures</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows a 3D anionic framework with three kinds of polynuclear clusters and 1D channels occupied by unknown charge-balancing guest solvent molecules. Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in triclinic space group <mml:math altimg="si1.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mi>P</mml:mi>
<mml:mover accent="true">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mn>1</mml:mn>
</mml:mrow>
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mo>¯</mml:mo>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:mover>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:math>. There are four Cu(II) ions, two bptca<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands, one OH<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> group and two coordinated water molecules in the asymmetric coordination unit of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>a). Presumably, [(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> decomposed from DMA and H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> might be inclosed into the channels to fit the global charge balance of anionic framework . The guest cations are severely disordered, but whether the confirmation of the guest solvent molecules has little influence on the exploration of main frameworks. Cu1, Cu2 and Cu3 centers are five-coordinated, residing in a distorted square pyramidal geometry. Each Cu1 atom is linked with four oxygen atoms of four carboxylate groups from four bptca<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> linkers and one coordinated water molecule (Cu1–O 1.958(6)–2.144(9)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), Cu2 center is coordinated to four oxygen atoms from four separate bptca<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands and one oxygen atom of one hydroxyl (Cu2–O 1.916(5)–2.216(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), while Cu3 is bridged by three carboxylate oxygen atoms of three bptca<ce:sup loc="post">4-</ce:sup> anions and two hydroxyl oxygen atoms (Cu3–O 1.923(6)–2.207(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). Cu4 adopts a distorted octahedral geometry defined by five oxygen atoms of four carboxylate groups from three bptca<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> linkers in consideration of a nonnegligible Cu4–O16 interaction of 2.653<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and one coordinate water ligand (Cu4–O 1.925(6)–2.384(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). For the two independent bptca<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>

cln_elements.clean_text:
Description of the crystal structures

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 1 shows a 3D anionic framework with three kinds of polynuclear clusters and 1D channels occupied by unknown charge-balancing guest solvent molecules. Complex 1 crystallizes in triclinic space group   P   1   ¯    . There are four Cu(II) ions, two bptca4 - ligands, one OH- group and two coordinated water molecules in the asymmetric coordination unit of 1 ( a). Presumably, [(CH3)2NH2]+ decomposed from DMA and H3O+ might be inclosed into the channels to fit the global charge balance of anionic framework . The guest cations are severely disordered, but whether the confirmation of the guest solvent molecules has little influence on the exploration of main frameworks. Cu1, Cu2 and Cu3 centers are five-coordinated, residing in a distorted square pyramidal geometry. Each Cu1 atom is linked with four oxygen atoms of four carboxylate groups from four bptca4 - linkers and one coordinated water molecule (Cu1-O 1.958(6)-2.144(9)Å), Cu2 center is coordinated to four oxygen atoms from four separate bptca4 - ligands and one oxygen atom of one hydroxyl (Cu2-O 1.916(5)-2.216(6)Å), while Cu3 is bridged by three carboxylate oxygen atoms of three bptca4- anions and two hydroxyl oxygen atoms (Cu3-O 1.923(6)-2.207(6)Å). Cu4 adopts a distorted octahedral geometry defined by five oxygen atoms of four carboxylate groups from three bptca4 - linkers in consideration of a nonnegligible Cu4-O16 interaction of 2.653Å and one coordinate water ligand (Cu4-O 1.925(6)-2.384(5)Å). For the two independent bptca4 - anions in 1, one exhibits a μ8-bridging mode with the carboxylate groups in μ2-η1:η1 and μ2-η1:η2 fashions ( a). The other tetracarboxylate features a μ6-bridging mode with μ2-η1:η1 and μ1-η1:η0 fashions of carboxylate groups (b).

Significantly, the assembly of paddle-wheel clusters as rigid SBUs with polytopic carboxylate linkers could generate rigid porous frameworks with permanent porosity and open functionalized metal sites . As a consequence, Cu2(COO)4 paddle-wheel subunits for different orientations act as square SBUs linking 1D chains to provide a 3D framework with regular 1D parallelogram nanosized channels along the a axis (grid dimensions of 10.55×9.42Å2, calculated from the neighboring Cu(II) atoms) (c). Furthermore, two different kinds of square apertures are present. The first one is polar owing to the effective pore surface occupied mainly by uncoordinate carboxylate oxygen atoms and coordinate aqua molecules, and the twisted benzenyl groups of bptca4 - take up the second hydrophobic channels. When seen from a  ×  b plane, the framework structure of 1 is closely compact (), and thus, show noninterpenetrating single network, which depends on the asymmetrical nature of the bptca4 - molecules possessing long molecular backbone to stretch space and large metal clusters laterally to block the interpenetrating aisles. A calculation using platon revealed that the potential total solvent-accessible void space of the framework is 1072.2Å3, corresponding to the 43.5% of the unit cell volume 2466.1Å3 . From the view of topology, the SBUs of dimer [Cu2O2] subunit and tetranuclear [Cu4(μ 3-OH)2] cluster serve as 4-connected and 8-connected nodes, respectively. The bptca4 - ligands show two kinds of coordinated modes, but both of them link four copper-based SBUs, and thus, the organic ligands act as 4-connected nodes. So, the whole 3D framework adopts an unusual tetranodal (4,4,4,8)-connected net with the point symbol of {412.812.104}{43.83}4{46}{86} (d).

Except for the molar ratio variation of reactants, the assembly of the same starting materials as those of 1 offers the other complex 2, in which single Cu2(COO)4 paddle-wheel supporting layers interacting with mononuclear Cu(bptca)2 result in a 3D anionic nanoporous framework. Single-crystal XRD analysis makes clear that complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with space group C2/c. As shown in  a, the asymmetric unit of 2 contains three Cu2+ ions, two deprotoned bptca4- ligands, three coordinated water molecules. Fitting the global charge balance of anionic nanoporous framework 2 from the same starting materials as 1 should be similar to that of complex 1. Each Cu(II) center is five-coordinated mode of distorted square pyramidal geometry. Cu1 is coordinated by four oxygen atoms from four carboxylate groups of four isophthalate moieties of four bptca4- (Cu1-O 1.957(5)-1.987(5)Å) and one oxygen atom from one terminal water (Cu1-O9 2.134(6)Å). Whereas, the mononuclear Cu2 is surrounded by four oxygen atoms of four monodentate carboxylates from two phthalates of two bptca4 - in the equatorial positions (Cu2-O 1.869(9)-1.951(9)Å), and the axial oxygen atom of coordinated aqua molecule (Cu2-O10 2.408(18)Å). The bptca4 - ligand exhibits a unique μ5-bridging mode with the carboxylate groups in μ2-η1:η1 and μ1-η1:η0 fashions (c).

Two adjacent Cu1 ions are linked by four bidentate bridging carboxylate groups to afford a paddle-wheel Cu2(COO)4 subunit with the Cu-Cu distance of 2.6391(18)Å, being shorter than that of complex 1 (b). Due to the different coordination environment of Cu atoms, the respective paddle-wheel units in 1 and 2, also display some differences, which each bptca4 - ligand of 1 connects only one paddle-wheel cluster and the cation of 2 does two paddle-wheel clusters. The Cu2(COO)4 fragment gets ulteriorly incorporation with four neighboring paddle-wheel clusters via two bidentate bridging carboxylate groups of isophthalate to give a single Cu2(COO)4 paddle-wheel supporting grid structure. These 2D layers are linked in the third direction by folded mononuclear Cu(bptc)2 units, to form a 3D nanoporous framework (c). Similar to 1, the framework accommodates infinite open 1D quadrate channels with 11.20Å caliber (Cu…Cu distance). Meanwhile, the closely arrangement of the components on the a  ×  b or a  ×  c plane suggests the noninterpenetrating features of the final framework (). The potential solvent-accessible volume of 2 is 2129.5Å3, which corresponds to 42.7% of unit cell volume 4991.0Å3 according to the platon calculations . From the viewpoint of the network topology, 2 possesses 3D (4,4)-connected binodal frameworks with {42.84} PtS-type topology, by considering each mononuclear Cu(bptca)2 and paddle-wheel Cu2(COO)4 clusters as 4-connected nodes (d).

Complexes 1 and 2 are air-stable and can retain the crystalline integrity at ambient conditions. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) show that 1 and 2 have onset weight losses within the temperature range of 125-240°C and 110-205°C, respectively ( ). The first steps of TGA curves correspond to the release of the unknown disordered solvent molecules. Almost without pause, the host MOFs begin to decompose continuously until the final products CuO obtained. Consequently, the final MOFs exhibit ordinary thermal stability, which can be attributed to the anion nature of the frameworks strengthened by charge-balancing guest cations.
